Local Adaptivity in Federated Learning: Convergence and Consistency

Jianyu Wangâ€ , Zheng XuÂ§, Zachary GarrettÂ§, Zachary CharlesÂ§, Luyang LiuÂ§, Gauri Joshiâ€ 

â€ Carnegie Mellon University, Â§Google Research Work performed while doing an internship at Google Research. Emails: jianyuw1@andrew.cmu.edu, {xuzheng, zachgarrett, zachcharles, luyangliu}@google.com, gaurij@andrew.cmu.edu
Abstract

The federated learning (FL) framework trains a machine learning model using decentralized data stored at edge client devices by periodically aggregating locally trained models. Popular optimization algorithms of FL use vanilla (stochastic) gradient descent for both local updates at clients and global updates at the aggregating server. Recently, adaptive optimization methods such as AdaGrad have been studied for server updates. However, the effect of using adaptive optimization methods for local updates at clients is not yet understood. We show in both theory and practice that while local adaptive methods can accelerate convergence, they can cause a non-vanishing solution bias, where the final converged solution may be different from the stationary point of the global objective function. We propose correction techniques to overcome this inconsistency and complement the local adaptive methods for FL. Extensive experiments on realistic federated training tasks show that the proposed algorithms can achieve faster convergence and higher test accuracy than the baselines without local adaptivity.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is an emerging paradigm to perform distributed machine learning model training on decentralized edge clients (e.g., mobile phones or IoT devices) under the orchestration of a central server, while keeping private training data on the client devicesÂ [1]. In the cross-device FL setting, a global model is usually trained by a collaborative process of thousands or even millions of participating clients. In each training round of FL, the central server broadcasts the global model to a random subset of clients to perform local model training, and each participated client only uploads the model parameter changes back to the server. Then, the server aggregates local changes to update the global model and continues the next round. This FL training procedure was proposed byÂ McMahan etÂ al. [2] as the federated averaging (FedAvg) algorithm, and widely applied in diverse applicationsÂ [3, 4, 5].

Recently, Reddi etÂ al. [6] proposed a generalization of FedAvg referred to as FedOpt. FedOpt is a flexible algorithmic framework that allows the clients and the server to choose different optimization methods (which are referred to as ClientOpt and ServerOpt) more general than stochastic gradient descent (SGD) in FedAvg. The key idea is to treat the aggregated local changes from clients as a â€œpseudo-gradientâ€ and use it as input to ServerOpt when updating the global model. A few previous works explored the choices of server optimizer (ServerOpt) in the FedOpt framework. For example, Hsu etÂ al. [7], Wang etÂ al. [8] used SGD with momentum at the server while keeping client optimizer as SGD and observed significant empirical improvements.

Adaptive methods, such as AdaGradÂ [9, 10], AdamÂ [11], have achieved superior empirical performance over SGD in centralized training of machine learning models for some applications. In particular, Adam and its variantsÂ [12, 13, 14] are widely recognized as the preferred optimizers for language-related training tasks. Motivated by their superior performance, Reddi etÂ al. [6] studied a specific class of FedOpt, where ClientOpt is still SGD but ServerOpt uses adaptive methods. It has been validated through extensive experiments inÂ [6, 15] that the server-only adaptive methods can achieve faster convergence than vanilla FedAvg in many federated training tasks.

Despite the success of using server-side adaptive methods, the power of adaptivity has not been fully utilized in the FedOpt framework, particularly on the client side. Instead of using adaptive methods only in ServerOpt for periodical updates per communication round, one can also choose to use adaptive methods in ClientOpt for every local iteration, or in both ClientOpt and ServerOpt. Client adaptive methods can accelerate the local convergence by better utilizing the geometric information of the local objectives. Unfortuantely, there are little to no literature exploring this promising direction. It remains an open problem whether the faster local convergence can be translated into faster global convergence and savings in communication rounds.

In this paper, we explore the usage of local adaptive methods and provide affirmative answers to the question: Can federated learning effectively use adaptive optimization methods on local clients? Specifically, our main contributions are listed as follows.

1. We identify that naively changing ClientOpt in the FedOpt framework from SGD to adaptive methods or other stateful optimizers can be problematic, as it does not define how to update client optimizer states (i.e., pre-conditioners and momentum buffers) across rounds. We propose to overcome this discontinuity issue by restarting the update of client optimizer states at the beginning of each round. This simple method enables the usage of local adaptivity in FedOpt. We also show that, on many practical training tasks, using adaptive optimizers on clients can achieve faster convergence and higher test accuracy than previous methods. color=blue!25, inline] Zheng: The previous sentence seems to be a bit vague and the logic on how it connects to the first sentence is not quite clear to me. What is the proposed method, and how did it overcome the issue described in the first sentence? Maybe just merge the two, drop the "identified" claim, and just directly describe we have a method to overcome the challenge. color=yellow!25, inline] Jianyu: Rephrase the complete part.

2. We further provide a theoretical analysis for strongly convex functions to understand the effects of various client optimizers. Our theorem suggests that performing FedOpt can be viewed as finding the fixed points of some operator ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’œ]ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ’œ{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}], the expression of which is determined by client optimizers. Local adaptivity can change ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’œ]ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ’œ{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}] in a way that yields faster convergence. However, this enhanced optimization may come with the cost of a non-vanishing solution bias â€“ the point we converge to may be far away from the global minimizer of the original objective function, as illustrated in FigureÂ 1.

3. In order to overcome the side effects of using adaptive client optimizers, we propose (1) local correction technique that can help to mitigate the non-vanishing solution bias; (2) global correction technique that can help to perserve the fast convergence property of adaptive methods. Using one or both of them on the top of adaptive client optimizers can achieve the highest test accuracy on all considered federated training tasks.

Related Works. In terms of using adaptive methods on clients, Xie etÂ al. [16], Karimireddy etÂ al. [17] proposed to use the same optimizer states (pre-conditioners and momentum buffers) on all clients, which is similar to server adaptive methods in [6] and does not exploit local adaptivity. To the best of our knowledge, this paper is the first to let clients separately update their optimizer states and study the effects of adaptive client optimizers. Besides, there are few recent literatureÂ [18, 19, 20, 21] also study the phenomenon that FedAvg-style algorithms can converge to a mismatched solution from the optimal one. We refer readers to SectionÂ 4 for detailed comparisons with these works. At last, within the FedOpt framework, there are many more building blocks that can accelerate the convergence or improve the practical performance, for instance, using control variatesÂ [22, 17, 23], regularizing the local objective functions [24, 25, 26], sampling important clients more frequently [27, 28, 29]. In this paper, we focus on an important but rarely studied topic â€“ local adaptivity, which is orthogonal and complementary to the above previous works. color=blue!25, inline] Zheng: optional: I am not sure if claiming complementary is good enough or we want to be stronger on the difference, e.g., we care more of a cross-device settings with stateless clients. 3 How to Apply Adaptive Methods on Clients

In this section, we describe the challenges of using local adaptivity in FedOpt and propose a simple, yet effective method to enable the usage of local adaptivity in FedOpt without incurring additional communication costs.

Challenge in FedOpt: Discontinuity of Client Optimizer States. According to the update rules 4 andÂ 5 of FedOpt, we observe that FedOpt can not be directly applied to adaptive client optimizers, as it lacks the articulation of handling the initial optimizer states ğ’”isubscriptğ’”ğ‘–\bm{s}_{i} across rounds and clients. To be specific, in FedOpt, the client updates are isolated not only from each other but also from different rounds due to the local iterations. While FedOpt uses ServerOpt to bridge the gap between local iterates in different rounds (i.e., it specifies how to obtain ğ’™(t+1)superscriptğ’™ğ‘¡1\bm{x}^{(t+1)} from {ğ’™i(t,Ï„i)}superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğœğ‘–\{\bm{x}_{i}^{(t,\tau_{i})}\}), it does not define how to update the initial optimizer states ğ’”isubscriptğ’”ğ‘–\bm{s}_{i} across rounds. We refer to this problem as discontinuity of client optimizer states.

A natural but impractical idea to tackle the discontinuity problem is to let each client inherit its own client optimizer states from previous rounds. However, these previous states can be stale and inaccurate because they are evaluated at point ğ’™i(tâˆ’1,Ï„i)superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘–ğ‘¡1subscriptğœğ‘–\bm{x}_{i}^{(t-1,\tau_{i})} and do not take account of the possibly dramatic changes from ğ’™i(tâˆ’1,Ï„i)superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘–ğ‘¡1subscriptğœğ‘–\bm{x}_{i}^{(t-1,\tau_{i})} to the current iterate ğ’™(t)superscriptğ’™ğ‘¡\bm{x}^{(t)}. When the server only selects a random subset of clients at each round, the staleness will be further exacerbated, as one client may be disconnected from the server for multiple rounds. Besides, this solution is impossible in many applications of FL (e.g., the cross-device setting) that requires clients to be stateless and not to maintain any persistent states across rounds, due to privacy and system constraintsÂ [1]. Furthermore, one can also choose to synchronize the local optimizer states at the end of each round and use the synchronized states as the initial value for next round. For example, Yu etÂ al. [31] has used a similar strategy to synchronize momentum buffer when the clients use momentum SGD. However, in order to aggregate and broadcast the additional optimizer states, this strategy would incur doubled or tripled communication costs compared to FedOpt with vanilla SGD client optimizer.

Our Proposal: Restarting Client Optimizer States. To work with the above challenges, we propose a simple yet effective approach. Instead of applying potentially complicated mechanisms to synchronize optimizer states across clients, we restart the updates of client optimizer states at the beginning of each round. That is, resetting the pre-conditioners to a constant and resetting the momentum buffers to zero. This strategy does not require any information from previous rounds, so it is compatible with application settings that require stateless clients. Also, it does not incur addition communication costs, as only the local model changes are aggregated.

To verify the advantage of this simple strategy, in FigureÂ 1(b), we provide simulation results on a toy problem of quadratic functions with deterministic gradients. The result shows the restarting strategy on local AdaGrad (i.e., the green curve) can achieve significantly faster convergence speed, comparing to vanilla FedAvg (i.e., the blue curve) when the tolerance to the global optimal is relatively large. The fast convergence is also observed on practical federated training tasks (see FigureÂ 2 and more discussions in SectionÂ 6).

4 Effects of Client Optimizers on Convergence and Consistency

Another important observation from the toy example in FigureÂ 1(b) is that local AdaGrad converges to a point which is quite far away from the global optimum. Even if we decay the client learning rate, this inconsistency problem still cannot be mitigated or becomes even worse. In this section, we will theoretically analyze the effect of client optimizers on the convergence and provide insights into the trade-off between convergence speed and the consistency of the solution.

FedOpt Performs Fixed Point Iteration. When using the restarting strategy proposed in SectionÂ 3, the argument ğ’”isubscriptğ’”ğ‘–\bm{s}_{i} representing the initial optimizer state in the operator ğ’œisubscriptğ’œğ‘–\mathcal{A}_{i} can be omitted since it is set to its default initial value and is the same on all clients. We further define an operator ğ’œâ€‹(ğ’™)=âˆ‘i=1Mwiâ€‹ğ’œiâ€‹(ğ’™;Ï„i,Îi)ğ’œğ’™superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ’œğ‘–ğ’™subscriptğœğ‘–subscriptÎğ‘–\mathcal{A}(\bm{x})=\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}\mathcal{A}_{i}(\bm{x};\tau_{i},\Xi_{i}). Accordingly, the global update rule (see Eqn. 5) of FedOpt is equivalent to a stochastic fixed point iteration, shown as follows:

The deterministic version of 6 is known as Mannâ€™s iteration [32] and will converge to the fixed points of ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’œ]ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ’œ{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}] under certain conditions. Replacing server GD with another server optimizer can accelerate the convergence but it will not influence the properties and the fixed points of the operator ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’œ]ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ’œ{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}].

We will analyze the convergence of FedOpt (update rule of which is 6) in the setting where each local objective function Fiâ€‹(ğ’™)subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ’™F_{i}(\bm{x}) is Lisubscriptğ¿ğ‘–L_{i}-Lipschitz smooth and Î¼isubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–\mu_{i}-strongly convex. Besides, we make the following assumptions on the properties of each client optimizer ğ’œisubscriptğ’œğ‘–\mathcal{A}_{i} and show how the global convergence is influenced by these properties. If the client optimizer is SGD, then the contractive local operator and bounded cumulative variance properties described below follow directly from the strong convexity and smoothness of the objective function, suggesting the following assumptions are reasonable and mild.

Assumption 1 (Contractive Local Operator).

The local expected operator ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’œi]ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ’œğ‘–{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}_{i}] is contractive, satisfying that â€–ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’œiâ€‹(ğ±;k,Î)]âˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’œiâ€‹(ğ²;k,Î)]â€–2â‰¤hiâ€‹(k)â‹…â€–ğ±âˆ’ğ²â€–2superscriptnormğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ’œğ‘–ğ±ğ‘˜Îğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ’œğ‘–ğ²ğ‘˜Î2â‹…subscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘˜superscriptnormğ±ğ²2\left\|{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}_{i}(\bm{x};k,\Xi)]-{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}_{i}(\bm{y};k,\Xi)]\right\|^{2}\leq h_{i}(k)\cdot\left\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}\right\|^{2} for any ğ±,ğ²âˆˆâ„dğ±ğ²superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\bm{x},\bm{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, where 0<hiâ€‹(k)<10subscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘˜10<h_{i}(k)<1 is a decreasing function of the number of local steps kğ‘˜k.

Assumption 2 (Bounded Cumulative Variance).

We assume the local stochastic gradient gisubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–g_{i} is an unbiased estimator of âˆ‡Fiâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–\nabla F_{i} and has bounded variance: ğ”¼â€‹â€–giâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(ğ±)â€–2â‰¤Ïƒ2ğ”¼superscriptnormsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ±âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ±2superscriptğœ2{\mathbb{E}}\left\|g_{i}(\bm{x})-\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x})\right\|^{2}\leq\sigma^{2}. The function hiâ€‹(k)subscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘˜h_{i}(k) in AssumptionÂ 1 measures the local training progress of ClientOpt. In intuition, when ClientOpt has faster convergence rate or takes more local steps, the output of ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’œi]ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ’œğ‘–{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}_{i}] will be closer to the minimum ğ’™iâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘–\bm{x}_{i}^{*}, and hence hisubscriptâ„ğ‘–h_{i} will become smaller. Besides, the function qiâ€‹(k)subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘˜q_{i}(k) in AssumptionÂ 2 quantifies how the noise in stochastic gradients are accumulated through kğ‘˜k local updates. The analytical forms of hi,qisubscriptâ„ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–h_{i},q_{i} depend on the choice of ClientOpt. For example, when the client optimizer is SGD with fixed client learning rate, we formally prove in AppendixÂ B that hiâ€‹(k)=(1âˆ’Î·iâ€‹Î¼i)2â€‹ksubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘˜superscript1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘–subscriptğœ‡ğ‘–2ğ‘˜h_{i}(k)=(1-\eta_{i}\mu_{i})^{2k} and qiâ€‹(k)=Î·i2â€‹ksubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–2ğ‘˜q_{i}(k)=\eta_{i}^{2}k. For adaptive optimizers, such as AdaGrad and Adam, while it is difficult to obtain the analytical form of hisubscriptâ„ğ‘–h_{i}, we empirically validate AssumptionÂ 1 in SectionÂ B.4 and found they can yield smaller hisubscriptâ„ğ‘–h_{i} values than vanilla SGD.

Theorem 1 (Convergence of FedOpt and Minimizer Inconsistency).

Under AssumptionsÂ 1 andÂ 2, the operator ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’œ]ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ’œ{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}] is contractive and has a unique fixed point ğ±~~ğ±\widetilde{\bm{x}}. After total Tğ‘‡T communication rounds, the global iterates of FedOpt converge to ğ±~~ğ±\widetilde{\bm{x}} at the following rate for some positive constant cğ‘c:

ğ”¼â€‹â€–ğ’™(T)âˆ’ğ’™~â€–2â‰¤câ‹…([âˆ‘i=1Mwiâ€‹hi]Tâ€‹â€–ğ’™(0)âˆ’ğ’™~â€–21âˆ’âˆ‘i=1Mwiâ€‹hi+1Tâ€‹Ïƒ2â€‹âˆ‘i=1Mwi2â€‹qi(1âˆ’âˆ‘i=1Mwiâ€‹hi)2).ğ”¼superscriptnormsuperscriptğ’™ğ‘‡~ğ’™2â‹…ğ‘superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘‡superscriptnormsuperscriptğ’™0~ğ’™21superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptâ„ğ‘–1ğ‘‡superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–2subscriptğ‘ğ‘–superscript1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptâ„ğ‘–2\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}\|\bm{x}^{(T)}-\widetilde{\bm{x}}\|^{2}\leq c\cdot\left(\left[\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}h_{i}\right]^{T}\frac{\|\bm{x}^{(0)}-\widetilde{\bm{x}}\|^{2}}{1-\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}h_{i}}+\frac{1}{T}\frac{\sigma^{2}\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}^{2}q_{i}}{(1-\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}h_{i})^{2}}\right). (7)

In the presence of data heterogeneity, the fixed point ğ±~~ğ±\widetilde{\bm{x}} of ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’œ]ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ’œ{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}] is not necessarily the same as the optimum ğ±âˆ—superscriptğ±\bm{x}^{*} of the global objective Fğ¹F. We refer to this problem as minimizer inconsistency.

Better Client Optimizers Can Accelerate the Global Convergence. TheoremÂ 1 provides a nice connection between local and global convergence. Specifically, if clients use better client optimizers that have smaller contraction constant hisubscriptâ„ğ‘–h_{i}, then the worst-case global convergence to the fixed point ğ’™~~ğ’™\widetilde{\bm{x}} can be improved, as the error bound 7 monotonically increases with hisubscriptâ„ğ‘–h_{i}. Therefore, a natural strategy to speedup the global convergence is to separately minimize hisubscriptâ„ğ‘–h_{i} on each client while keeping qisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–q_{i} unchanged. One can achieve this by either tuning a proper learning rate for each client, or using adaptive client optimizers which could reduce the effective local condition number. Intuitively, using better client optimizers makes the operator ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’œ]ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ’œ{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}] to be more contractive, and hence, it becomes easier to find its fixed points (as corroborated in FigureÂ 1(a), the loss surface is better conditioned when using local AdaGrad). This acceleration effects is complementary to that of the server optimizer, which changes the form of the fixed point iteration without affecting ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’œ]ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ’œ{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}]. Therefore, one can use both better client and server optimizers to get the best performance, as we will later illustrate in SectionÂ 6.

The Minimizer Inconsistency Problem. TheoremÂ 1 also shows that the speedup effects of client optimizers may come with a price: the fixed point ğ’™~~ğ’™\widetilde{\bm{x}} can be different from the optimal minimizer ğ’™âˆ—superscriptğ’™\bm{x}^{*}. When the objective function is quadratic, ClientOpt is GD and all clients have the same learning rates Î·ğœ‚\eta and number of local steps Ï„ğœ\tau, it has been shown in [19, 20] that â€–ğ’™~âˆ’ğ’™âˆ—â€–=ğ’ªâ€‹(Î·â€‹(Ï„âˆ’1))norm~ğ’™superscriptğ’™ğ’ªğœ‚ğœ1\|\widetilde{\bm{x}}-\bm{x}^{*}\|=\mathcal{O}(\eta(\tau-1)) such that one can balance the trade-off between convergence speed and the minimizer inconsistency by gradually decaying the client learning rate. However, through a simple counterexample below, we will show that using adaptive optimizers or different hyper-parameters on clients leads to an additional gap between ğ±~~ğ±\widetilde{\bm{x}} and ğ±âˆ—superscriptğ±\bm{x}^{*}, which does not vanish to zero with the learning rate. This non-vanishing bias explains our empirical observations in FigureÂ 1(b) and calls for new techniques to overcome it.

This toy example also illustrates how local adaptivity can accelerate convergence. In particular, when the local pre-conditioners are ideal (i.e., inverse of local Hessians), FedOpt can converge to ğ’™~~ğ’™\widetilde{\bm{x}} in just one round by choosing proper server and client learning rates. But if the local pre-conditioner are the same across all clients (ğ‘·i=ğ‘·subscriptğ‘·ğ‘–ğ‘·\bm{P}_{i}=\bm{P}), then the convergence of FedOpt will depend on the condition numbers of {ğ‘·â€‹ğ‘¯i}ğ‘·subscriptğ‘¯ğ‘–\{\bm{P}\bm{H}_{i}\} and require multiple rounds.

Connections with Previous Works on Minimizer Inconsistency. When client learning rates, number of local steps are the same across all clients, and non-adaptive, deterministic ClientOpt are used, â€–ğ’™~âˆ’ğ’™âˆ—â€–norm~ğ’™superscriptğ’™\|\widetilde{\bm{x}}-\bm{x}^{*}\| can vanish to zero along with the learning rates. This phenomenon has been observed and analyzed by few recent literature in different forms, see [19, 21, 20]. TheoremÂ 1 generalizes these results by allowing heterogeneous local hyper-parameters and adaptive, stochastic client optimizers. In addition, the non-vanishing bias was studied in [18] by assuming different local learning rates and local steps at clients. In this paper, we further generalize the results by showing that even when the learning rates and local steps are the same, using local adaptive methods will lead to a non-vanishing gap. We summarize the differences in TableÂ 6 of AppendixÂ D.

5 Correction Techniques to Overcome the Non-vanishing Solution Bias

As we discussed in SectionÂ 4, while using faster client optimizers and exploiting local structures can help improve the global convergence, this strategy results in a non-vanishing gap between the converged point ğ’™~~ğ’™\widetilde{\bm{x}} and the optimal solution ğ’™âˆ—superscriptğ’™\bm{x}^{*}. Inspired by the quadratic example in SectionÂ 4, we propose (i) a local correction method that reweights local gradients before sending the client updates to the server in order to overcome the non-vanishing part of minimizer inconsistency, and (ii) a global correction method applied by the server when aggregating the client updates in order to preserve fast convergence.

Local Correction: Reweighting Local Gradients. From 10 in the quadratic example, one can observe that the non-vanishing minimizer inconsistency comes from the fact that FedOpt implicitly and improperly weights each local gradients by a matrix ğ‘µi=Î·iâ€‹Ï„iâ€‹ğ‘·isubscriptğ‘µğ‘–subscriptğœ‚ğ‘–subscriptğœğ‘–subscriptğ‘·ğ‘–\bm{N}_{i}=\eta_{i}\tau_{i}\bm{P}_{i}. So a natural solution to overcome the non-vanishing bias is to normalize the local model changes before aggregating them on the server. Instead of sending ğ’™âˆ’ğ’œiâ€‹(ğ’™)=ğ‘µiâ€‹âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(ğ’™)+ğ’ªâ€‹(Î·i2)ğ’™subscriptğ’œğ‘–ğ’™subscriptğ‘µğ‘–âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ’™ğ’ªsuperscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–2\bm{x}-\mathcal{A}_{i}(\bm{x})=\bm{N}_{i}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x})+\mathcal{O}(\eta_{i}^{2}) to the server, each client can send the locally normalized version ğ‘µiâˆ’1â€‹(ğ’™âˆ’ğ’œiâ€‹(ğ’™))superscriptsubscriptğ‘µğ‘–1ğ’™subscriptğ’œğ‘–ğ’™\bm{N}_{i}^{-1}(\bm{x}-\mathcal{A}_{i}(\bm{x})). This simple change can ensure that the first term in 10 is always zero no matter which value is the client learning rate. As a consequence, there is no non-vanishing solution bias. The local correction technique also automatically avoids the invalid solution ğ’™=ğ’œâ€‹(ğ’™),âˆ€ğ’™ğ’™ğ’œğ’™for-allğ’™\bm{x}=\mathcal{A}(\bm{x}),\forall\bm{x} by dividing the client learning rate.

The local correction technique can be extended to more general settings and work with any adaptive optimizers, such as AdaGrad, Adam. If the local model changes of a specific client optimizer can be written as ğ’™âˆ’ğ’œiâ€‹(ğ’™;Ï„i)=Î·iâ€‹âˆ‘k=0Ï„iâˆ’1ğ‘©i(k)â€‹âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(ğ’™(k))ğ’™subscriptğ’œğ‘–ğ’™subscriptğœğ‘–subscriptğœ‚ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜0subscriptğœğ‘–1superscriptsubscriptğ‘©ğ‘–ğ‘˜âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–superscriptğ’™ğ‘˜\bm{x}-\mathcal{A}_{i}(\bm{x};\tau_{i})=\eta_{i}\sum_{k=0}^{\tau_{i}-1}\bm{B}_{i}^{(k)}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x}^{(k)}) where ğ‘©i(k)superscriptsubscriptğ‘©ğ‘–ğ‘˜\bm{B}_{i}^{(k)} is symmetric and positive-definite and ğ’™(k)superscriptğ’™ğ‘˜\bm{x}^{(k)} denotes the kğ‘˜k-th iterate during local updates, then we can choose the local correction matrix to be ğ‘µi=Î·iâ€‹âˆ‘k=0Ï„iâˆ’1ğ‘©i(k)subscriptğ‘µğ‘–subscriptğœ‚ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜0subscriptğœğ‘–1superscriptsubscriptğ‘©ğ‘–ğ‘˜\bm{N}_{i}=\eta_{i}\sum_{k=0}^{\tau_{i}-1}\bm{B}_{i}^{(k)} such that

âˆ‘i=1Mwiâ€‹ğ‘µiâˆ’1â€‹(ğ’™âˆ—âˆ’ğ’œiâ€‹(ğ’™âˆ—))=âˆ‘i=1Mwiâ€‹âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(ğ’™âˆ—)âŸ=âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ’™âˆ—)â£=0+ğ’ªâ€‹(Î·iâ€‹Ï„i)=ğ’ªâ€‹(Î·iâ€‹Ï„i).superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘µğ‘–1superscriptğ’™subscriptğ’œğ‘–superscriptğ’™subscriptâŸsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–superscriptğ’™absentâˆ‡ğ¹superscriptğ’™absent0ğ’ªsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–subscriptğœğ‘–ğ’ªsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–subscriptğœğ‘–\displaystyle\textstyle\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}\bm{N}_{i}^{-1}(\bm{x}^{*}-\mathcal{A}_{i}(\bm{x}^{*}))=\underbrace{\textstyle{\sum_{i=1}^{M}}w_{i}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x}^{*})}_{=\nabla F(\bm{x}^{*})=0}+\mathcal{O}(\eta_{i}\tau_{i})=\mathcal{O}(\eta_{i}\tau_{i}). (11)

If the client optimizer is AdaGrad, then ğ‘©i(k)superscriptsubscriptğ‘©ğ‘–ğ‘˜\bm{B}_{i}^{(k)} is just the pre-conditioner ğ‘·i(k)superscriptsubscriptğ‘·ğ‘–ğ‘˜\bm{P}_{i}^{(k)} used at the kğ‘˜k-th local iteration; if the client optimizer is Adam, then ğ‘©i(k)superscriptsubscriptğ‘©ğ‘–ğ‘˜\bm{B}_{i}^{(k)} is a weighted summation of local pre-conditioners. In SectionÂ A.3, we provide the pseudo-code of finding the expression of ğ‘µisubscriptğ‘µğ‘–\bm{N}_{i} for common optimizers; and in AppendixÂ F, we formally prove that local correction can help FedOpt with deterministic client optimizers converge to the stationary points of the original objective function (even when it is non-convex). For stochastic client optimizers, we empirically validate the effectiveness of local correction through extensive experiments in SectionÂ 6.

Global Correction: Preserving the Fast Convergence. Equation 11 shows that using the local correction technique may change the scale of the aggregated model updates. In particular, the first-order approximation of the aggregated model updates just equals to plain gradients (the first term in 11) and may lose the local pre-conditioning effects. In order to address this problem, one can use either adaptive server optimizer that are more robust to the scale of its inputs, or a novel global correction technique that can help to preserve the scale of local updates. To be specific, in global correction, the server uses ğ‘µsâˆ’1â€‹âˆ‘i=1Mwiâ€‹ğ‘µiâˆ’1â€‹[ğ’™âˆ’ğ’œiâ€‹(ğ’™)]superscriptsubscriptğ‘µğ‘ 1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘µğ‘–1delimited-[]ğ’™subscriptğ’œğ‘–ğ’™\bm{N}_{s}^{-1}\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}\bm{N}_{i}^{-1}[\bm{x}-\mathcal{A}_{i}(\bm{x})] as the pseudo-gradient of ServerOpt, where ğ‘µssubscriptğ‘µğ‘ \bm{N}_{s} is given as ğ‘µs=âˆ‘i=1Mwiâ€‹ğ‘µiâˆ’1subscriptğ‘µğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘µğ‘–1\bm{N}_{s}=\sum_{i=1}^{M}w_{i}\bm{N}_{i}^{-1}. There may also exist other better choices of the matrix ğ‘µssubscriptğ‘µğ‘ \bm{N}_{s}. As long as ğ‘µssubscriptğ‘µğ‘ \bm{N}_{s} does not depend on the client index iğ‘–i, it will not influence the fixed point, to which the algorithm converge. We name this technique as global correction, because it is applied on the server side. In order to obtain ğ‘µssubscriptğ‘µğ‘ \bm{N}_{s}, the clients need to send the local correction matrices ğ‘µisubscriptğ‘µğ‘–\bm{N}_{i} to the server. But the server does not need to broadcast the correction matrix ğ‘µssubscriptğ‘µğ‘ \bm{N}_{s} back. Therefore, if matrices {ğ‘µi}subscriptğ‘µğ‘–\{\bm{N}_{i}\} are diagonal, then the communication cost per round of using global correction is only 1.5Ã—1.5\times than that of without using it. color=blue!25, inline] Zheng: We should probably have one sentence talking about algorithm 1 somewhere.

6 Experiments

In this section, we summarize the experimental results and validate the effectiveness of the proposed methods. Specifically, we show that FedOpt with local adaptivity and correction techqniues can achieve faster convergence, higher test accuracy, as well as more robustness against learning rate changes than previous server-only adaptive methods.

We focus on three language-related tasksÂ [6], which have the favored sparse structures for adaptive methods: (i) Next word prediciton using RNN on Stack Overflow (SO NWP); (ii) next character prediction using RNN on Shakespeare (Shakes. NCP); (iii) tag prediction using linear regression on Stack Overflow (SO TP). For the first two tasks, we report the validation/test accuracy. For SO TP task, we report the validation/test Recall@5. Moreover, we also evaluate the methods in image classification task on the CIFAR100 datasetÂ [33]. The detailed descriptions (hyper-parameter tuning ranges and choices) of these federated training tasks are provided in AppendixÂ A. Our implementation based on the Tensorflow Federated (TFF) package will be open-sourced.

Faster Convergence. In FigureÂ 2, we first compare the training curves of different ways of using AdaGrad in FedOpt on the SO NWP training task. One can either use AdaGrad on clients, or on the server, or on both. It can be observed that using local AdaGrad can significantly speedup the convergence compared to using vanilla SGD as the client optimizer. In particular, client-only AdaGrad is even slightly faster than server-only AdaGrad. When the local epoch increases from 111 to 555, the improvement of client-only AdaGrad over server-only AdaGrad becomes more obvious. If we apply AdaGrad on both clients and the server, then FedOpt achieves the fastest convergence (about 4Ã—4\times faster than server-only AdaGrad to achieve 20%percent2020\% validation accuracy in FigureÂ 2a).

Higher Final Accuracy. We further report the test accuracy or Recall@5 on different training tasks in TableÂ 1. Similar to the above discussions on faster convergence, changing ClientOpt from SGD to AdaGrad and using the restarting strategy prposed in sectionÂ 3 consistently improves the test accuracy on multiple training tasks. And applying AdaGrad on both clients and the server achieves the highest test accuracy. For example, when the ServerOpt is AdaGrad, the test accuracy improves from 21.80%percent21.8021.80\% to 24.40%percent24.4024.40\% on SO NWP, and from 57.68%percent57.6857.68\% to 57.85%percent57.8557.85\% on Shakes. NCP. However, note that on the SO TP task, server AdaGrad plus client AdaGrad with the restarting strategy performs worse than server-only AdaGrad (65.7965.7965.79 versus 66.3966.3966.39). This performance degradation may come from the non-vanishing solution bias, as we discussed in SectionÂ 4.

Then, we evaluate the proposed correction techniques in TableÂ 2 and compare the results with the best server-only adaptive methods on each training tasks (the best server optimizer is selected based on the results in [6]). On SO TP, by overcoming the non-vanishing bias, client AdaGrad with local correction can achieve much higher Recall@5 than vanilla SGD optimizer (67.0467.0467.04 versus 66.3966.3966.39). Similar improvements also appear in SO NWP and Shakes. NCP tasks. Besides client AdaGrad, our proposed methods also work for other common momentum-based adaptive optimizers (such as Adam and YogiÂ [13]). We present the experimental results on SO NWP in TableÂ 3. It can be observed that our proposed method relatively improves the test accuracy of server Adam plus client SGD by 3.9%percent3.93.9\% (25.35%percent25.3525.35\% versus 24.40%percent24.4024.40\%), and vanilla FedAvg by 78.6%percent78.678.6\% (25.35%percent25.3525.35\% versus 14.19%percent14.1914.19\%).

Less Sensitive to Hyper-parameter Changes. In FigureÂ 3, we report how the test accuracy changes with server and client learning rates on the SO NWP task. We observe that for server-only AdaGrad, there is only two out of 282828 learning rate combinations that can achieve a 20%+limit-frompercent2020\%+ test accuracy. On the other hand, using AdaGrad on both clients and server are more robust to the learning rate changes. There are 101010 out of 282828 combinations reaching a 20%+limit-frompercent2020\%+ test accuracy. The less sensitivity to learning rate changes can help people to save hyper-parameter tuning time in practice.

Comparison with the Synchronizing States Strategy. We further compare the proposed restarting optimizer states strategy to a synchronizing strategy where local pre-conditioners are synchronized after each round. Surprisingly, the additional communication in the synchronized strategy does not help and achieves even worse accuracy. For instance, on Shakes. NCP, server AdaGrad plus synchronized client AdaGrad has a test accuracy of 56.89%percent56.8956.89\%, which is lower than that of the restarting one (57.85%percent57.8557.85\%).

Results on Image Classification Task. At last, we examine the performance of the proposed methods on pathological version of CIFAR100, following the setup in [6]. The observations are similar to language related tasks. Naively using client adaptive methods in FedOpt is not guaranteed to have better performance. But when combining local adaptvity with the proposed correction techniques, the performance consistently improves. Specifically, after 800080008000 communication rounds, while server Adam plus client AdaGrad has worse test accuracy than server-only Adam (54.68%percent54.6854.68\% vs 56.64%percent56.6456.64\%), using local correction can improve the accuracy to 56.80%percent56.8056.80\%.

7 Conclusions

In this paper, we first propose techniques that enable the use of adaptive optimization methods for local updates at clients in federated learning. Through the analysis on effects of client optimizers for smooth and strongly convex functions, we show that although local adaptive methods can accelerate the convergence in some scenarios, it introduces an additional non-vanishing gap between the converged point and the optimal solution. To mitigate the side effects of using local adaptivity, we further propose local and global correction techniques. We verified the advantages of the proposed methods regarding fast convergence, better test accuracy with extensive experiments on benchmark datasets.

Appendix A Experimental Details

In this section, we describe our experimental setup in more detail. A brief summary of tunning ranges and default values for hyper-parameters are summarized in TableÂ 4.

A.1 Training Tasks

Next-Word Prediction on Stack Overflow (SO NWP for short).

Stack Overflow is a language modeling dataset from the question and answer site, Stack Overflow. The datasets consists of questions and answers from 342,477342477342,477 unique users, each of which is treated as a client in our experiments. We perform next-word prediction task on this dataset and restrict to the 10,000 most frequently used words. The preprocess procedure of this datasets follows [6]. Specifically, we let each client only use the first 128 sentences of its local dataset, in order to avoid that clients have extremely different amount of data. Padding and truncation are used to ensure that sentences have 20 words. The metrics we report are the top-1 validation and test accuracy over the 10,0001000010,000-word vocabulary. It does not include padding, out-of-vocab, or beginning or end or sentence tokens. The neural network model we use is a RNN with single LSTM layer, which is the same as that of [6].

Tag Prediction on Stack Overfolow (SO TP for short).

Tag prediction via logistic regression is another training task on the Stack Overflow datasets. It has the same number of clients and vocabulary size as SO NWP. Besides, following the setup in [6], we use the 500500500 most frequent tags and a one-versus-rest classification strategy.

Next Character Prediction on Shakespeare (Shakes. NCP for short).

Shakespeare is another language modeling dataset built from the works from William Shakespeare. Each client corresponds to a speaking role with at least two lines. The lines of each speaking role is splitted into sequences of 80 characters, padding if necessary. The vocabulary size is 90. The neural networks model we use is the same as [6]: a RNN with two LSTM layers.

A.2 Best Performing Hyper-parameters

We report the best performed hyper-parameters in TableÂ 5. The hyper-parameters are selected in a way such that the average validation accuracy (or recall@5) over the last 100100100 rounds achieves the highest value.

A.3 Pseudo-Codes of The Proposed Algorithms

We present the pseudo-codes for our proposed algorithms in AlgorithmÂ 1. It is worth noting that AlgorithmÂ 1 only provides a concrete specification of the proposed local and global correction techniques. Beyond our choices, there may exist many other algorithmic variants.

(21)

This completes the proof of the first inequality in Lemma 2. Using the similar technique as above, one can prove that

â€–ğ”¼â€‹[Hâ€‹(ğ’™âˆ’ğ’š)âˆ’Î¼â€‹(ğ’™âˆ’ğ’š)]â€–2â‰¤superscriptnormğ”¼delimited-[]ğ»ğ’™ğ’šğœ‡ğ’™ğ’š2absent\displaystyle\left\|{\mathbb{E}}[H(\bm{x}-\bm{y})-\mu(\bm{x}-\bm{y})]\right\|^{2}\leq (Lâˆ’Î¼)â€‹âŸ¨ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’™âˆ’ğ’š],ğ”¼â€‹[(ğ‘¯âˆ’Î¼â€‹ğ‘°)â€‹(ğ’™âˆ’ğ’š)]âŸ©.ğ¿ğœ‡ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ’™ğ’šğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘¯ğœ‡ğ‘°ğ’™ğ’š\displaystyle(L-\mu)\left<{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}-\bm{y}]},\,{{\mathbb{E}}[(\bm{H}-\mu\bm{I})(\bm{x}-\bm{y})]}\right>. (22)

Besides, note that

â€–ğ”¼â€‹[Hâ€‹(ğ’™âˆ’ğ’š)âˆ’Î¼â€‹(ğ’™âˆ’ğ’š)]â€–2=superscriptnormğ”¼delimited-[]ğ»ğ’™ğ’šğœ‡ğ’™ğ’š2absent\displaystyle\left\|{\mathbb{E}}[H(\bm{x}-\bm{y})-\mu(\bm{x}-\bm{y})]\right\|^{2}= â€–ğ”¼â€‹[Hâ€‹(ğ’™âˆ’ğ’š)]â€–2+Î¼2â€‹â€–ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’™âˆ’ğ’š]â€–2superscriptnormğ”¼delimited-[]ğ»ğ’™ğ’š2superscriptğœ‡2superscriptnormğ”¼delimited-[]ğ’™ğ’š2\displaystyle\left\|{\mathbb{E}}[H(\bm{x}-\bm{y})]\right\|^{2}+\mu^{2}\left\|{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}-\bm{y}]\right\|^{2}
âˆ’2â€‹Î¼â€‹âŸ¨ğ”¼â€‹[ğ‘¯â€‹(ğ’™âˆ’ğ’š)],ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’™âˆ’ğ’š]âŸ©.2ğœ‡ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘¯ğ’™ğ’šğ”¼delimited-[]ğ’™ğ’š\displaystyle-2\mu\left<{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{H}(\bm{x}-\bm{y})]},\,{{\mathbb{E}}[\bm{x}-\bm{y}]}\right>. (23)

(24)

Here we complete the proof of the last inequality in Lemma 2. âˆ

B.4 Empirical Validations for Adaptive Client Optimizers

While for vanilla SGD client optimizer, we can get the analytical expressions of hi,qisubscriptâ„ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–h_{i},q_{i} in AssumptionsÂ 1 andÂ 2, it can be complicated to perform the same analysis for adaptive client optimizers. So in this subsection, we are going to provide some empirical evidence that adaptive optimizers (such as Adam) also satisfies AssumptionÂ 1 and can yield smaller hisubscriptâ„ğ‘–h_{i} values than vanilla SGD.

In particular, we evaluate the performance of vanilla SGD and Adam on the MNIST datasetÂ [34]. For each optimizer, we train two logistic regression models, which start from two different initial points ğ’™,ğ’šğ’™ğ’š\bm{x},\bm{y} but traverse the same sequence of mini-batches of data. After repeating the same experiment multiple times with different random seeds, we report hi=â€–ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’œiâ€‹(ğ’™;k)]âˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’œiâ€‹(ğ’š;k)]â€–2/â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’šâ€–2subscriptâ„ğ‘–superscriptnormğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ’œğ‘–ğ’™ğ‘˜ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ’œğ‘–ğ’šğ‘˜2superscriptnormğ’™ğ’š2h_{i}=\|{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}_{i}(\bm{x};k)]-{\mathbb{E}}[\mathcal{A}_{i}(\bm{y};k)]\|^{2}/\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}\|^{2} in FigureÂ 4. One can observe that, given a number of local steps kğ‘˜k, Adam can have a smaller value of hisubscriptâ„ğ‘–h_{i} than vanilla SGD.

In order to get the final convergence rate, we need a technical lemma from [35], stated as follows.

Substituting 84 into 78, we have

ğ”¼â€‹â€–ğ’™(T)âˆ’ğ’™~â€–2â‰¤ğ”¼superscriptnormsuperscriptğ’™ğ‘‡~ğ’™2absent\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}\left\|\bm{x}^{(T)}-\widetilde{\bm{x}}\right\|^{2}\leq 9â€‹Ïƒ2Î¼2â€‹Mâ€‹Ï„â€‹(T+Î²)9superscriptğœ2superscriptğœ‡2ğ‘€ğœğ‘‡ğ›½\displaystyle\frac{9\sigma^{2}}{\mu^{2}M\tau(T+\beta)} (85)

which matches the lower bound of local SGD in the IID data settingÂ [37], in which all local operator share the same fixed point ğ’™~=ğ’™âˆ—=ğ’™iâˆ—~ğ’™superscriptğ’™superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘–\widetilde{\bm{x}}=\bm{x}^{*}=\bm{x}_{i}^{*} for all iğ‘–i.

Appendix D Connection with Previous Works on the Minimizer Inconsistency

When client learning rates, number of local steps are the same across all clients, and non-adaptive, deterministic ClientOpt are used, â€–ğ’™~âˆ’ğ’™âˆ—â€–norm~ğ’™superscriptğ’™\|\widetilde{\bm{x}}-\bm{x}^{*}\| can vanish to zero along with the learning rates. This phenomenon has been observed and analyzed by few recent literature in different forms, see [19, 21, 20]. TheoremÂ 1 generalizes these results by allowing heterogeneous local hyper-parameters and adaptive, stochastic client optimizers. In addition, the non-vanishing bias was studied in [18] by assuming different local learning rates and local steps at clients. In this paper, we further generalize the results by showing that even when the learning rates and local steps are the same, using local adaptive methods will lead to a non-vanishing gap. We summarize the differences in TableÂ 6.

Appendix F Proof for the Convergence of Local Correction

Our convergence analysis will be centered around the following assumptions.

Assumption 3.

Each local objective is Lipschitz smooth, that is, â€–âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(ğ²)â€–â‰¤Lâ€‹â€–ğ±âˆ’ğ²â€–,âˆ€iâˆˆ[M]formulae-sequencenormâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ±âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ²ğ¿normğ±ğ²for-allğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘€\left\|\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x})-\nabla F_{i}(\bm{y})\right\|\leq L\left\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}\right\|,\forall i\in[M].

Assumption 4.

The matrices {ğ€i(t,k)}superscriptsubscriptğ€ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘˜\{\bm{A}_{i}^{(t,k)}\} are positive-definite symmetric matrices and have bounded operator norm: â€–ğ€i(t,k)â€–opâ‰¤Î›/Ï„isubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ€ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘˜opÎ›subscriptğœğ‘–\left\|\bm{A}_{i}^{(t,k)}\right\|_{\tiny{\mbox{op}}}\leq\Lambda/\tau_{i}.

Assumption 5.

The pre-conditioned gradients at each local iteration have bounded norm, i.e., â€–ği(t,k)â€‹âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(ğ±i(t,k))â€–â‰¤Gnormsuperscriptsubscriptğğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘˜âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğº\left\|\bm{B}_{i}^{(t,k)}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x}_{i}^{(t,k)})\right\|\leq G.

Theorem 3 (Convergence Guarantee for Local Correction Technique).

Suppose all clients have the same client learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta and the same number of local sptes Ï„ğœ\tau. Under AssumptionsÂ 3, 4 andÂ 5, if the server learning rate is set as Î±=Î·â€‹Ï„â‰¤1/Lğ›¼ğœ‚ğœ1ğ¿\alpha=\eta\tau\leq 1/L and the client learning rate is

Î·=minâ¡{1Ï„â€‹L,1Ï„â€‹T13â€‹(DL2â€‹Î›â€‹G2)13}ğœ‚1ğœğ¿1ğœsuperscriptğ‘‡13superscriptğ·superscriptğ¿2Î›superscriptğº213\displaystyle\eta=\min\left\{\frac{1}{\tau L},\frac{1}{\tau T^{\frac{1}{3}}}\left(\frac{D}{L^{2}\Lambda G^{2}}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}\right\} (99)

where D=Fâ€‹(ğ±(0))âˆ’Finfğ·ğ¹superscriptğ±0subscriptğ¹infD=F(\bm{x}^{(0)})-F_{\text{inf}}, then the global iterate 98 converges at the following rate:

mintâˆˆ[0,T]â¡â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ’™(t))â€–2=ğ’ªâ€‹(1T+Î›13â€‹G23T23).subscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹superscriptğ’™ğ‘¡2ğ’ª1ğ‘‡superscriptÎ›13superscriptğº23superscriptğ‘‡23\displaystyle\min_{t\in[0,T]}\left\|\nabla F(\bm{x}^{(t)})\right\|^{2}=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{T}+\frac{\Lambda^{\frac{1}{3}}G^{\frac{2}{3}}}{T^{\frac{2}{3}}}\right). (100)

It is worth noting that the convergence rate 100 matches previous results in [39, 40] in the deterministic, non-IID data setting. TheoremÂ 3 shows that using adaptive client optimizers together with local correction can preserve the same convergence rate as vanilla GD client optimizer and there is no non-vanishing solution bias.
